awd_titl_txt: The oUTCT PEN:  Outwardly Mobilizing the UTCT Vertebrate Archive for Research and Training
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Texas High-Resolution X-ray CT Facility (UTCT) was established in 1997 to make HRXCT - a direct descendant of medical CT - available to researchers in the natural sciences.  Through this award, oUTCT will partner with the oVert (openVertebrate) project to make nearly nine terabytes of existing high-resolution X-ray computed tomographic (HRXCT) data publicly accessible, and to train the next generation of students in best practices for these data.  Scientists from around the world have brought their most important and precious natural history specimens to UTCT to image and measure their interior features nondestructively.  This application of HRXCT technology has been tremendously successful, resulting in the proliferation of scanners at institutions across the country.  Over the course of two years, oUTCT will upload HRXCT data for 90 UTCT clients to MorphoSource.  About 3000 specimen scans, representing nearly 1,500 fossil and extant vertebrate species, will be made available so they can be easily discovered and downloaded by everyone from scientists to artists to K-12 educators.  This mobilization will be accomplished by undergraduate students employed at UTCT, who will learn the basics of HRXCT data acquisition and visualization as well as basic bioinformatics.

The UTCT datasets, acquired in part via dozens of NSF grants and cited more than 18,000 times in academic publications, remain in high demand due to their broad scope, high data quality, and historical significance.  This demand has been fueled in part by the public-facing Digital Library of Morphology (DigiMorph.org), an NSF-funded project online since 2002 and housed at UTCT, which serves HRXCT-derived animations for more than 1,000 biological and paleontological specimens.  In the oUTCT project, UTCT and DigiMorph will partner with oVert and iDigBio, both at the University of Florida, and the MorphoSource data repository at Duke University to make this unparalleled collection of HRXCT datasets more readily discoverable and more easily repurposed.  As part of the educational outreach for this project, oUTCT will also provide training to the oVert community, which spans nearly 20 universities and academic institutions, to maximize the scientific impact of that project.  The UTCT will host two short courses per year, cosponsored by oVert and iDigBio, to train students and scientists associated with oVert and MorphoSource in the fundamentals of HRXCT data acquisition, visualization, analysis, and long-term management. These activities will expand the impact of the original oVert project and maximize the return on NSF?s investment in it, UTCT, DigiMorph, iDigBio, and MorphoSource.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In recent years, federal funding agencies increasingly have supported FAIR principles (Findability, Accessibility, Interoperability, and Reuse) for data generation and stewardship, and Open Science goals that include broadly sharing publications and datasets for the benefit of society and via an open process of knowledge creation, evaluation, and communication. These efforts not only benefit society, but also increase the impact of its financial investment in these funding agencies. This project, oUTCT, sought to meet these standards.

The University of Texas High-Resolution X-ray CT Facility (UTCT) was established in 1997 to make HRXCT technology available to academic researchers worldwide. HRXCT scanning makes it possible to ‘look inside’ precious natural history specimens completely nondestructively. Over the last 28 years UTCT has scanned the most famous fossils in the world, including the oldest-known dinosaurs (Eoraptor, Herrerasaurus), the first bird (Archaeopteryx), and the most complete human ancestor fossil ‘Lucy’ (Australopithecus), as well as important extant taxa like the ‘living fossil fish’ coelacanth (Latimeria) and the ivory-billed woodpecker (Campephilus).

Through oUTCT, UTCT was able to partner with the openVertebrate Project (oVert) to mobilize nearly three terabytes of data from its archives to MorphoSource.org (Duke University), the preeminent repository for HRXCT data of biological and paleontological specimens. These data were acquired for 90 UTCT clients from 64 institutions and nine countries. Nearly 2,600 media from nearly 2,000 specimens were uploaded as part of oUTCT, in part representing data produced by 72 projects funded by 11 different NSF Divisions.  This effort to increase the findability and accessibility – and therefore, reuse – of HRXCT data generated at UTCT has yielded terrific results thus far, with more than 6,400 download requests to MorphoSource. These download requests are not just from researchers, but also from K-12 educators, artists, exhibit designers, and more. Approximately 50 peer-reviewed publications and dissertations utilizing data made available by oUTCT have been published to date.

The other component of oUTCT was training. The project employed six undergraduates (four of them female) who learned how to work with HRXCT data to prepare them for upload to MorphoSource. They also had the opportunity to participate in UTCT’s annual short courses, made possible by NSF Shared Multi-User Facility support, which teach best practices for specimen selection and imaging and provide hands-on training in visualization and analysis of HRXCT data.

Finally, oUTCT itself hosted four short courses, offering the same basic training in HRXCT data acquisition, analysis, and visualization, as well as guidance in repositing data to MorphoSource. These short courses targeted the oVert and MorphoSource community, and a total of 59 participants from 41 institutions in five countries took part.

The impact of oUTCT will extend far beyond the end of the grant. The undergraduate and graduate students, postdocs, faculty, and museum staff who received training working for oUTCT or attending its short courses will continue to employ that knowledge in their research and education. And, the ongoing discovery and reuse of oUTCT data uploaded to MorphoSource not only furthers FAIR principles and Open Science goals but also increases the value of the original NSF investment in the acquisition of those data.

 


Last Modified: 12/27/2024
Modified by: Jessica A Maisano
